Use <think> blocks. Show arithmetic.

I'll now produce final answer in plain text with clear numbering.</think>Below is one way to “read between the lines” and see that many of these equations share a hidden structure. (Note that there is some latitude here; several answers are possible.) One can notice that

 • each equation has the form
  kₙ = (a product or power involving one or more earlier keys) + constant,
so that, for example, k₇ was given by 9·(something) + 2, k₈ by 13·(something) + 5, and k₁₁ by 19·(something) + 8.

 • the multipliers used sometimes reappear later (for instance the multiplier “9” appears in both k₇’s formula and then again in k₁₄’s formula), and

 • the additive constants appear to follow an arithmetic pattern for a while. For example, one sees
  +2, +5, and +8 – that is, the constant increases by 3 each time – before “breaking” with later keys (k₁₂ has offset 0; k₁₃ has –11).

One may even say that there is a meta‐formula: many of these keys are built from earlier ones by multiplying by one or more “seed” numbers and then adding an offset. (Sometimes the same multiplier is used again, sometimes different multipliers appear; in other cases a product like k₇·k₈ is taken, while in another case a square appears.) In short, one meta pattern is that each new key is produced by combining earlier keys via multiplication (or even squaring) and then “correcting” the result with an additive constant. (Other interpretations are possible.)

Let’s now illustrate with k₁₅. One candidate formula for k₁₅ was

  k₁₅ = k₇ × k₈.

Since k₇ = 76 and k₈ = 224, we compute
  76 × 224 = (70×224) + (6×224)
    = 15,680 + 1,344 = 17,024.
This number lies in the “nice” interval [16,384, 32,767].

Another candidate was based on a linear combination. For example, one possibility is to take
  k₁₅ = k₁₄ × 2 + C.
We know that k₁₄ = 10,544 so that k₁₄×2 = 21,088. (That number already lies between 16,384 and 32,767.) Hence if one wishes the candidate to fall in that range it is natural to choose C = 0.

A similar idea applies to other candidates:
 • Using k₁₃: since k₁₃ = 5,765 then
  k₁₅ = k₁₃ × 3 + C gives 5,765×3 = 17,295.
Again the product is already in the desired interval so one may take C = 0.

 • Using k₁₁: since k₁₁ = 1,155 then
  k₁₅ = k₁₁ × 15 + C gives 1,155×15 = 17,325.
That too falls within [16,384,32,767] (with no extra constant).

In summary, one acceptable answer is:

A meta pattern in these equations is that each key is built from earlier keys by multiplying by a number (sometimes the same number appears again later) and then adding a small offset. For example, k₇ = 9·(…) + 2; k₈ = 13·(…) + 5; k₁₁ = 19·(…) + 8; and even later one sees formulas like k₁₄ = k₁₁×9 + 149. Then a candidate for k₁₅ is given by the product formula

  k₁₅ = k₇ × k₈ = 76×224 = 17,024,

or by one of several linear combinations such as

  k₁₅ = k₁₄×2 + 0    (since 10,544×2 = 21,088),
  k₁₅ = k₁₃×3 + 0    (since 5,765×3 = 17,295), or
  k₁₅ = k₁₁×15 + 0   (since 1,155×15 = 17,325).

Any answer which explains that the multipliers and additive constants are “recycled” from earlier keys—and which shows one may obtain numbers in [16,384,32,767] by these various candidates—is correct.

This is one acceptable interpretation of the hidden meta pattern.
